reviews.review:
As someone with no nostalgic connections to this game, I have to say that Half Life lived up to the hype. Plays quite well for a game released in 1998 and you could see how it revolutionized the FPS genre and focused more on other things besides mindless shooting. In Half Life, you have to solve puzzles, rely on NPCs, parkour (rather extremely I might add. You are going to have a rough time if you don't know how to crouch-jump), and observe your surroundings.

The high point of the game for me has to be the NPC interactions with you and the environment. They react when getting hit, they talk to each other, they talk to you and are your primary source of story-telling, and come off as real people. Reminds me of older Halo titles where the NPCs would talk about their surroundings and actions to make the game world feel alive. Too many games simply put a name tag on their NPCs but I can say that Half Life does a great job in making their NPCs feel real, I always felt the need to keep them safe and was sad if they died.

The only downside I had with the game was the audio direction. There is this weird audio effect where sounds will play slightly after they played for the first time, giving this echo effect. At first I thought this was a glitch but it turns out this was intentional to give the feeling of noises bouncing off the walls in the cramp spaces of the Black Mesa Research Facility. After I learned this was intentional, I felt a bit less aggravated but I wish there were an option to disable it. There is a command to disable it although it resets back to the usual echo when you enter a room designated for the audio effect.

This game is wonderful! The pacing is perfect, I played through the whole games in just a few days and never got bored of playing for long sittings. The game is able to move from a small scale survival horror style game to a big military shooter to a weird space alien shooter/platformer without ever changing it's core game play, only changing the weapons available to you and the level design. The graphics hold up very well for a game so old imo, nothing stood out to me as looking bad even if the game does obviously look dated since it's like 24 years old at this point.

A game that can stand up 24 years later, that can be very enjoyable for someone just playing it for the first time so long after its original release is a really amazingly well designed game. It has some issues but nothing that held me back from seriously enjoying myself while playing it.
Turns out a crossbow and a crowbar are all you'll need if aliens ever decide to invade earth
